AcceptedAnswer:
You need a fractional linear (a.k.a. projective linear) change of variable
$$
x' = \frac{rx+s}{tx+u},
$$
with coefficients $r,s,t,u$ chosen so that the map $x \mapsto x'$
is an involution taking $a,b,c,d$ to $c,d,a,b$.  Explicitly you can take
$$
r = ac-bd, \quad
s = bcd - acd + abd - abc, \quad
t = a - b + c - d, \quad
u = bd-ac
$$
(note that $u = -r$, which is necessary and sufficient for a
fractional linear transformation to be its own functional inverse).
This transformation takes each of the integrals
$\int_a^b dx \, / \sqrt{|f(x)|}$ and $\int_c^d dx \, / \sqrt{|f(x)|}$ 
to the other, proving that they are equal.
